Article.ArticleTitle: A novel equation that incorporates the linear and hyperbolic nature of the force-velocity relationship in lower and upper limb exercises.

AbstractText: The purpose of this study is to provide a force-velocity (F-V) equation that combines a linear and a hyperbolic region, and to compare its derived results to those obtained from linear equations. A total of 10 cross-training athletes and 14 recreationally resistance-trained young men were assessed in the unilateral leg press (LP) and bilateral bench press (BP) exercises, respectively. F-V data were recorded using a force plate and a linear encoder. Estimated maximum isometric force (F<sub>0</sub>), maximum muscle power (P<sub>max</sub>), and maximum unloaded velocity (V<sub>0</sub>) were calculated using a hybrid (linear and hyperbolic) equation and three different linear equations: one derived from the hybrid equation (linear<sub>hyb</sub>), one applied to data from 0 to 100% of F<sub>0</sub> (linear<sub>0-100</sub>), and one applied to data from 45 to 100% of F<sub>0</sub> (linear<sub>45-100</sub>). The hybrid equation presented the best fit to the recorded data (R<sup>2</sup> = 0.996 and 0.998). Compared to the results derived from the hybrid equation in the LP, significant differences were observed in F<sub>0</sub> derived from linear<sub>0-100</sub>; V<sub>0</sub> derived from linear<sub>hyb</sub>, linear<sub>0-100</sub> and linear<sub>45-100</sub>; and P<sub>max</sub> derived from linear<sub>hyb</sub> and linear<sub>45-100</sub> (all p < 0.05). For the BP, compared to the hybrid equation, significant differences were found in F<sub>0</sub> derived from linear<sub>0-100</sub>; and V<sub>0</sub> and P<sub>max</sub> derived from linear<sub>hyb</sub>, linear<sub>0-100</sub> and linear<sub>45-100</sub> (all p < 0.05). An F-V equation combining a linear and a hyperbolic region showed to fit adequately recorded F-V data from ~ 20 to 100% of F<sub>0</sub>, and overcame the limitations shown by linear equations while providing relevant results.
